title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will conduct night patrols of community ecoguards along the 14 km Mani Beach throughout the marine turtle nesting season, conduct a turtle release program with fisherman at Grand Bereby, and conduct education and awareness campaigns in three local villages adjacent to Mani Beach.

title.narrative: Conservation of sea turtles of Ivory Coast

description.narrative: The goal of the project is to research and protect, with the assistance of Naval Police agents and the local community, the marine turtle nesting populations of Ivory Coast and their habitat.

title.narrative: Conservation of sea turtles of Ivory Coast

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to implement a sea turtle conservation project in Ivory Coast. Ivory Coast hosts important olive ridley, green and leatherback nesting and important foraging grounds for several sea turtle species. The intent of this project is to address threats to sea turtles from poaching and fisheries bycatch mortality. Activities include: 1) conducting community based night patrols along the 30 km Roc-Mani-Kablake Beach and 8 km Asseoufoue beach throughout the marine turtle nesting season to prevent poaching of nests and nesting females, 2) nests threatened by tides will be relocated to safe beach hatcheries, and 3) working with fisherman to safely release turtles caught in gill nets in Grand Bereby area

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Study and conservation of chimpanzees of Comoe National Park, Ivory Coast

description.narrative: The purpose of this 1-year project is to conserve and study Como National Park's western chimpanzees and their habitat. Specific activities include: 1) determining population, group size, structure, and home-range of three study groups of chimpanzees around the Como Research Station; 2) developing local capacity by training park personnel in biomonitoring sampling, and engaging neighboring villages in the project and park conservation; 3) determining the main threats to the chimpanzees and main entrance corridors for illegal activities; 4) developing a long term study, surveillance and sustainable management plan.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Reinforcing the Capacity to Implement CITES Legislation in Practice in Cote dIvoire

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to facilitate the combat of illegal wildlife trafficking in Cote dIvoire by strengthening the capacity of Ivorian Authorities to implement their obligations under CITES, specifically targeting West African regional transboundary movement of protected wildlife species and their products as a precursor to international trafficking.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Reinforcing the Capacity to Implement CITES Legislation in Practice in Cote dIvoire

description.narrative: (1) increasing the capacity to implement CITES among targeted law enforcement personnel in Cote dIvoire through training workshops for 150 wildlife and border control agents and development of identification guides; and (2) raising awareness of CITES and national wildlife laws among targeted public sectors in Cote dIvoire through development and diffusion of wildlife and wildlife parts identification tools for enforcement agents.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: SUPPORTING THE GOVERNMENT OF COTE D'IVOIRE TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF THEIR IVORY STOCKPILES

description.narrative: FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO HELP THE GOVERNMENT OF IVORY COAST IMPLEMENT A STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR ITS ELEPHANT IVORY. IVORY COAST IS CONSIDERED BOTH A COUNTRY OF ORIGIN AND TRANSIT FOR IVORY, AND RECENT SEIZURES SUGGEST THE CAPITAL CITY, ABIDJAN, IS AN INTERNATIONAL TRAFFICKING HUB FOR WILDLIFE PRODUCTS ORIGINATING IN WEST, EAST AND CENTRAL AFRICA. THE APPLICANT CURRENTLY PARTNERS WITH NINE COUNTRIES TO BETTER SECURE IVORY STOREROOMS, TO IMPROVE ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY, AND TO REDUCE THE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CORRUPTION RELATED TO THEFT OF IVORY FROM GOVERNMENT HOLDINGS. ACCORDING TO THE APPLICANT, NO COUNTRY THAT IS USING THE PROPOSED STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM HAS REPORTED A LOSS OF IVORY FROM STOREROOMS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) DIGITIZING THE CURRENT IVORY STOCKPILE AND ESTABLISHING A CLEAR AND ACCOUNTABLE CHAIN OF CUSTODY AND MANAGEMENT PROCESS (2) INSTALLING A DATABASE AND SERVER TO ARCHIVE INVENTORY DATA AND ALLOW FOR REAL TIME AND REMOTE ACCESS TO THAT DATA AND (3) TRAINING ADMINISTRATORS TO EFFECTIVELY OPERATE THE STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Supporting the Government of Cote dIvoire to improve the management of their ivory stockpiles,

description.narrative: (1) digitizing the current ivory stockpile and establishing a clear and accountable chain of custody and management process; (2) installing a database and server to archive inventory data and allow for real-time and remote access to that data; and (3) training administrators to effectively operate the stockpile management system.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF SEA TURTLES IN COTE D'IVOIRE

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROJECT IN IVORY COAST. IVORY COAST HOSTS IMPORTANT OLIVE RIDLEY, GREEN AND LEATHERBACK NESTING AND IMPORTANT FORAGING GROUNDS FOR SEVERAL SEA TURTLE SPECIES. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THREATS TO SEA TURTLES FROM POACHING AND FISHERIES BYCATCH MORTALITY. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 CONDUCTING COMMUNITY BASED NIGHT PATROLS ALONG THE 30 KM ROC-MANI-KABLAKE BEACH AND THE 8 KM ASSEOUFOUE BEACH THROUGHOUT THE MARINE TURTLE NESTING SEASON TO PREVENT POACHING OF NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES, 2 RELOCATING NESTS THREATENED BY TIDES TO SAFE BEACH HATCHERIES, AND 3 WORKING WITH FISHERMAN TO SAFELY RELEASE TURTLES CAUGHT IN GILL NETS IN GRAND BEREBY AREA.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF SEA TURTLES IN COTE D'IVOIRE

description.narrative: The activities of the project are: .1. Research and monitoring: Strengthening the system of beach surveys with a team of fifteen .villagers in order to locate all nesting females and nests, and to collect basic data on the Roc- Mani.Kablak beach; .2. Capacity-building: Reinforcing the capacities of community-based committee members in sea .turtle conservation and research; .3. Protection of all nesting females and nests: Developing strategies to protect all the females and .nests of the Roc-Mani-Kablak beach; .4. Surveys of the marine habitat and surveillance of the nearby fishing port of Grand Brby by the .Naval Police; .2 .5. Community-based conservation: Implementing an information, education, and communication .(IEC) program in beaches east of Grand Brby, maintenance of all the social and livelihood .structures (drinking water supply systems, community meeting houses, schools), and building .additional social infrastructure; .6. Fund raising: Submitting grant proposals to other sponsors to expand project activities to the .nearby beaches and in particular to manage the Grand-Brby Marine Protected Area; .7. Protecting the sea turtles of beaches east of Grand Brby by establishing a system of beach .monitoring with a team of at least six villagers.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF SEA TURTLES IN COTE D'IVOIRE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to implement a sea turtle conservation project in Ivory Coast. Ivory Coast hosts important olive ridley, green and leatherback nesting and important foraging grounds for several sea turtle species. The intent of this project is to address threats to sea turtles from poaching and fisheries bycatch mortality. Activities include: 1) conducting community based night patrols along the 30 km Roc-Mani-Kablake beach and the 8 km Asseoufoue beach throughout the marine turtle nesting season to prevent poaching of nests and nesting females, 2) relocating nests threatened by tides to safe beach hatcheries, and 3) working with fisherman to safely release turtles caught in gill nets in Grand Bereby area

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HOME S HINGE-BACK TORTOISE IN COTE D IVOIRE, WEST AFRICA. COTE D IVOIRE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to address threats to this species from exploitation for meat and medicinal.needs. An estimated five percent of the total population is collected each year which is steadily driving.populations towards extinction. Activities include: (1) documenting the population status in Tai, Azagny,.and Iles Ehotile National Parks and surrounding areas through field surveys; (2) conducting market.surveys in villages around the aforementioned parks; (3) providing turtles rescued from bushmeat markets.with health checks and care in preparation for translocation to soft release pens for a minimum of 12.months in suitable habitat near planned release sites; (4) ensuring healthy rescued turtles are released at.sites in Tai, Azagny, and Iles Ehotile National Parks (the number is yet to be determined and depends on.how many will be rescued); (5) outfitting at least 20 of the released rescued turtles with radio tags and.tracking them for at least six months to assess post-release behaviors, adaptation and survivorship to.inform future releases; and (6) training of park personnel in survey methods, data collection and radio.tracking techniques to carry out survey and protection within the parks.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HOME S HINGE-BACK TORTOISE IN COTE D IVOIRE, WEST AFRICA. COTE D IVOIRE

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THREATS TO THIS SPECIES FROM EXPLOITATION FOR MEAT AND MEDICINAL NEEDS. AN ESTIMATED FIVE PERCENT OF THE TOTAL POPULATION IS COLLECTED EACH YEAR WHICH IS STEADILY DRIVING POPULATIONS TOWARDS EXTINCTION. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 DOCUMENTING THE POPULATION STATUS IN TAI, AZAGNY, AND ILES EHOTILE NATIONAL PARKS AND SURROUNDING AREAS THROUGH FIELD SURVEYS 2 CONDUCTING MARKET SURVEYS IN VILLAGES AROUND THE AFOREMENTIONED PARKS 3 PROVIDING TURTLES RESCUED FROM BUSHMEAT MARKETS WITH HEALTH CHECKS AND CARE IN PREPARATION FOR TRANSLOCATION TO SOFT RELEASE PENS FOR A MINIMUM OF 12 MONTHS IN SUITABLE HABITAT NEAR PLANNED RELEASE SITES 4 ENSURING HEALTHY RESCUED TURTLES ARE RELEASED AT SITES IN TAI, AZAGNY, AND ILES EHOTILE NATIONAL PARKS THE NUMBER IS YET TO BE DETERMINED AND DEPENDS ON HOW MANY WILL BE RESCUED 5 OUTFITTING AT LEAST 20 OF THE RELEASED RESCUED TURTLES WITH RADIO TAGS AND TRACKING THEM FOR AT LEAST SIX MONTHS TO ASSESS POST-RELEASE BEHAVIORS, ADAPTATION AND SURVIVORSHIP TO INFORM FUTURE RELEASES AND 6 TRAINING OF PARK PERSONNEL IN SURVEY METHODS, DATA COLLECTION AND RADIO TRACKING TECHNIQUES TO CARRY OUT SURVEY AND PROTECTION WITHIN THE PARKS.
